aicpa-topic.title: Agency Transactions

body.p: 5.67 Unlike a principal transaction in which the broker-dealer is the counterparty to the transaction with the customer and, therefore, would have the securities transactions flow through its inventory because it is acting in a dealer capacity. Conversely, in an agency transaction, the broker-dealer is simply an intermediary between two counterparties transacting in the same security. Therefore, the securities transaction does not flow through its inventory because it is acting in a broker capacity.

5.68 FASB ASC 940-20-25-1 explains that transactions executed by broker-dealers as agents for customers are not reflected in the statement of financial condition of the broker-dealer unless the transaction fails to settle on the contracted settlement date. Because the broker-dealer typically delivers cash or financial instruments on behalf of the customer, if the customer fails on the settlement date, the broker-dealer is required to record the transaction (for example, as a fail-to-receive from customer, payable to customer, or stock borrowed or loaned on behalf of customer).

5.69 In accordance with FASB ASC 940-20-25-2, for securities purchased, commissions should be recorded as a receivable from customers; for securities sold, commissions should be recorded as reductions in the payable to customers. The commission income should be recognized in revenue by the broker-dealer when (or as) it satisfies its performance obligations under the contract in accordance with FASB ASC 606. Related expenses should be accrued by the broker-dealer on the trade date because substantially all the efforts in generating the commissions have been completed. Commission income should be accounted for using the five-step revenue recognition model within FASB ASC 606. Paragraphs 5.6.01–5.6.32 of chapter 5 of AICPA Audit and Accounting Guide Revenue Recognition, contain the related revenue recognition implementation issue for brokers and dealers in securities applying FASB ASC 606 (see paragraph 5.136 of this chapter). This content is presented in the “Revenue Streams” section under the headings “Commission Income” and “Recognition on Trade Date.”
